are an American professional [[basketball]] team based in [[Los Angeles]]. The Lakers compete in the [[National Basketball Association]] (NBA) as a member of the [[Pacific Division (NBA)|Pacific Division]] of the [[Western Conference (NBA)|Western Conference]]. The Lakers play their home games at [[Crypto.com Arena]], an arena they share with the [[Los Angeles Sparks]] of the [[Women's National Basketball Association]] and the [[Los Angeles Kings]] of the [[National Hockey League]].{{cite web|title=About Us|url=https://www.cryptoarena.com/arena-info/about-us|publisher=L.A. Arena Company, LLC|website=CryptoArena.com|access-date=March 1, 2023|archive-date=March 1, 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230301034354/https://www.cryptoarena.com/arena-info/about-us|url-status=live}} The Lakers are one of the most successful teams in the history of the NBA with 17 championships, the second most in the league behind the [[Boston Celtics]].{{cite news|last=Reynolds|first=Tim|title=Sweet 17: Lakers tie Celtics for most NBA championships|url=https://www.nba.com/news/lakers-tie-celtics-most-nba-championships|publisher=NBA Media Ventures, LLC|website=NBA.com|date=October 11, 2020|access-date=March 1, 2023|archive-date=March 1, 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230301034354/https://www.nba.com/news/lakers-tie-celtics-most-nba-championships|url-status=live}} The franchise began in 1946 as the [[Detroit Gems]] of the [[National Basketball League (United States)|National Basketball League]] (NBL). After one season, a new ownership relocated the team to [[Minneapolis]], Minnesota,{{cite news |author1=Sopan Deb |title=The Celtics Have 18 Championships. The Lakers? 17. (And Maybe One More.) |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2024/06/18/sports/celtics-lakers-nba-champions.html |access-date=8 September 2024 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=18 June 2024 |quote=A truly terrible N.B.L. team was the Detroit Gems, which played for only one season, going 4-40 in 1946-1947. Benny Berger, a Minneapolis businessman, purchased the Gems and relocated the franchise to Minneapolis. He renamed them the Lakers.}} and renamed the team as the ''Minneapolis Lakers''.{{cite news |author1=Jim Peltz |title=Name that team: How major pro sports franchises came by their names |url=https://www.latimes.com/sports/la-xpm-2013-dec-14-la-sp-sports-nicknames-history-20131215-story.html |access-date=8 September 2024 |work=[[The Los Angeles Times]] |date=14 December 2014 |quote=When the Detroit Gems were moved to Minneapolis before the 1947-48 season, they settled on Lakers because of Minnesota’s thousands of lakes.}} The Lakers won the 1948 NBL championship before joining the rival [[Basketball Association of America]], where they won the 1949 BAA championship. Following the merger of the NBL and the BAA into the NBA in 1949, the Lakers won four of the next five NBA championships.{{cite encyclopedia|last=Barreiro|first=Dan|title=George Mikan: The First Icon|url=http://www.nba.com/history/players/mikan_icon_050602.html|encyclopedia=From the Official NBA Encyclopedia, Third Edition|publisher=NBA.com|access-date=November 20, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121109214011/http://www.nba.com/history/players/mikan_icon_050602.html|archive-date=November 9, 2012|url-status=dead}} After struggling financially in the late 1950s, they [[relocation of professional sports teams|relocated]] to Los Angeles before the [[1960–61 NBA season|1960–61 season]]. The Lakers made the [[NBA Finals]] six times in the 1960s, but lost every series to the Celtics, beginning [[Celtics–Lakers rivalry|their long and storied rivalry]]. In 1968, the Lakers acquired four-time [[NBA Most Valuable Player Award|NBA Most Valuable Player]] (MVP) [[Wilt Chamberlain]], and won their sixth NBA title in [[1971–72 NBA season|1972]], led by coach [[Bill Sharman]]. After the retirement of Chamberlain, the team traded for superstar [[Kareem Abdul-Jabbar]]. Two big changes came in 1979, first, [[Jerry Buss]] purchased the Lakers, and pioneered a vision of basketball as entertainment as well as sport.{{cite news|last=Ostler|first=Scott|title=Remembering Jerry Buss and 'Showtime'|url=http://www.sfgate.com/sports/ostler/article/Remembering-Jerry-Buss-and-Showtime-4288541.php|access-date=February 21, 2013|newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle|date=February 19, 2013|archive-date=May 29, 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230529104108/http://www.sfgate.com/sports/ostler/article/Remembering-Jerry-Buss-and-Showtime-4288541.php|url-status=live}} Second, the Lakers drafted [[Magic Johnson]] [[List of first overall NBA draft picks|first overall]] in the [[1979 NBA draft]]. The combination of Johnson, a prodigy [[point guard]], and dominant [[Center (basketball)|center]] in Abdul-Jabbar provided the Lakers with superstars to anchor their roster. The promotion of head coach [[Pat Riley]] in 1981 and addition of forward [[James Worthy]] through the [[1982 NBA draft|1982 draft]] established the Lakers as an NBA powerhouse throughout the 1980s. The franchise won five championships in a nine-year span, including two out of three marquee Finals matchups against the Celtics. The Lakers were defeated by their Boston archrivals in the [[1984 NBA Finals|1984 Finals]], but triumphed over them in [[1985 NBA Finals|1985]] and [[1987 NBA Finals|1987]]. After Riley departed and Abdul-Jabbar, Johnson, and Worthy retired, the Lakers struggled in the early 1990s. It was not until 1996 when the team traded with the [[Charlotte Hornets]] for the draft rights to [[Kobe Bryant]] and signed center [[Shaquille O'Neal]] that the Lakers returned to dominance during the early 2000s. The superstar duo, along with Hall of Fame coach [[Phil Jackson]], led the Lakers to three consecutive championships between [[2000 NBA Finals|2000]] and [[2002 NBA Finals|2002]], securing the franchise's second "[[three-peat]]".{{Cite book |last=Pearlman |first=Jeff |url=https://search.worldcat.org/title/1269511608 |title=Three-Ring Circus: Kobe, Shaq, Phil, and the Crazy Years of the Lakers Dynasty |publisher=Mariner Books |year=2021 |isbn=978-0-358-62796-8 |oclc=1269511608 |access-date=January 31, 2024 |archive-date=January 31, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240131120124/https://search.worldcat.org/title/1269511608 |url-status=live }} The dynamic "[[Shaq–Kobe feud|Shaq-and-Kobe]]" era ended when the Lakers traded away O'Neal after the team lost to the [[Detroit Pistons]] in the [[2004 NBA Finals|2004 Finals]]. It was not until the Lakers traded for [[Pau Gasol]] that Bryant and Jackson returned to the NBA Finals, losing to the Celtics in [[2008 NBA Finals|2008]] but winning championships in [[2009 NBA Finals|2009]] and [[2010 NBA Finals|2010]]. The 2010 Finals marked the latest matchup of the Lakers and Celtics, with Los Angeles winning its 16th title. Jackson retired in 2011, and the Lakers endured their longest playoff drought in franchise history. Gasol departed in 2014, and Bryant retired in 2016. After rebuilding seasons with young, highly rated prospects, the Lakers signed superstar [[LeBron James]] in 2018.{{cite web|last=Youngmisuk|first=Ohm|title=LeBron James agrees to four-year, $153.3 million deal with Lakers|url=https://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/23967725/lebron-james-joining-los-angeles-lakers-4-year-1533-million-deal|website=[[ESPN]]|date=July 1, 2018|access-date=December 26, 2021|archive-date=April 10, |website=[[ESPN]]}} The Lakers—led by James, Davis, and coach [[Frank Vogel]]—won the team's 17th championship in [[2020 NBA Finals|2020]], tying the Celtics for the most titles until 2024.{{cite web|last=Ganguli|first=Tania|title=LeBron James leads Lakers to 17th championship and beats Heat in six games in Finals|url=https://www.latimes.com/sports/lakers/story/2020-10-11/lakers-vs-heat-game-6|website=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=October 11, 2020|access-date=October 11, 2020|archive-date=November 17, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211117054508/https://www.latimes.com/sports/lakers/story/2020-10-11/lakers-vs-heat-game-6|url-status=live}} The Lakers hold the record for [[List of NBA longest winning streaks|NBA's longest winning streak]], 33 straight games, set in 1971–72.{{cite web|title=All-Time Longest Win Streaks in NBA History|url=https://www.nba.com/2013/history/03/14/all-time-longest-win-streaks-in-nba-history/|publisher=NBA Media Ventures, LLC|website=NBA.com|date=March 14, 2013|access-date=March 17, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180218084016/http://www.nba.com/2013/history/03/14/all-time-longest-win-streaks-in-nba-history/|archive-date=February 18, 2018|url-status=dead}} 26 Hall of Famers have played for Los Angeles, while four have coached the team. Abdul-Jabbar, Johnson, O'Neal, and Bryant won a combined eight NBA MVP awards with the Lakers.{{cite web |url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/awards/mvp.html |title=Most Valuable Player Award Winners |access-date=July 7, 2008 |publisher=basketball-reference.com |archive-date=June 29, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629041314/http://www.basketball-reference.com/awards/mvp.html |url-status=dead }} ==History== {{Main|History of the Los Angeles Lakers}} ===1946–1954: Beginnings and Minneapolis dynasty with George Mikan=== [[File:Benjamin Berger speaking at the National Jewish Fund Dinner.jpg|upright|thumb|Minneapolis team co-owner Benjamin Berger]] The franchise was founded in 1946 as the [[Detroit Gems]] and played in the [[National Basketball League (United States)|National Basketball League]] (NBL) during the 1946–47 season where it finished last in the league with only 4 wins in 44 games. Though the team was scheduled to continue in the NBL the following season,{{cite news |title=Gems retain NBL franchise |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/97845620/ |access-date=8 September 2024 |work=[[Detroit Free Press]] |date=12 May 1947 |page=12 |via=[[Newspapers.com]]}}{{closed access}} its ownership, faced with high losses due to low attendance and lack of homecourt, decided on selling the team to [[Ben Berger]] and [[Morris Chalfen]] of [[Minnesota]] for $15,000{{cite news |title=Pro cagers say adieu |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/97720353/ |access-date=8 September 2024 |work=[[Detroit Free Press]] |date=4 June 1947 |page=16 |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |quote=Morris Winston, Dearborn merchant who backed the Gems last season, has sold the franchise to Benny Berger of Minneapolis. The club will operate as a Twin Cities entry next season.}}{{closed access}}{{cite news |title=Detroit Gems Nat'l cage franchise sold |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/365272201/ |access-date=8 September 2024 |work=[[The Herald-Palladium|The Herald-Press]] |agency=[[Associated Press]] |date=4 January 1947 |language=en |via=[[Newspapers.com]]}}{{closed access}} Minneapolis sportswriter [[Sid Hartman]] played a key behind-the-scenes role in helping put together the deal and later the team.Lazenby, p. 19. Inspired by Minnesota's nickname, "Land of 10,000 Lakes", the team rechristened themselves the Lakers.{{cite news |author1=Jerry Crowe |title=Minneapolis sportswriter helped raise the Lakers |url=https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-2009-apr-27-sp-crowe-nest27-story.html |access-date=8 September 2024 |work=[[The Los Angeles Times]] |date=27 April 2009 |quote=In the summer of 1947, Hartman says, “I went to Detroit with a check in my hand. We bought the Gems for 15 grand.” Later, in the so-called “Land of 10,000 Lakes,” a naming contest determined that they would be rechristened the Lakers.}}{{cite web|title=1956–57 Minneapolis Lakers Roster and Statistics|url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/teams/MNL/1957.html|publisher=basketball-reference.com|access-date=November 10, 2010|archive-date=October 9, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211009124314/https://www.basketball-reference.com/teams/MNL/1957.html|url-status=live}} Hartman helped them hire [[John Kundla]] from [[University of St. Thomas (Minnesota)|College of St. Thomas]], to be their first head coach, by meeting with him and selling him on the team.Lazenby, p. 18.{{cite web|url=http://www.startribune.com/getting-john-kundla-to-coach-minneapolis-lakers-no-easy-task/385323501/|title=Getting John Kundla to coach Minneapolis Lakers no easy task|work=[[Star Tribune]]|date=July 3, 2016 |access-date=July 5, 2016|archive-date=August 22, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210822202618/https://www.startribune.com/getting-john-kundla-to-coach-minneapolis-lakers-no-easy-task/385323501/|url-status=live}} As the franchise had the worst record in the NBL the previous season, it got the first pick in the 1947 [[Professional Basketball League of America]] dispersal draft, which they used to select [[George Mikan]]. Led by Mikan, the Lakers had a solid roster, which also featured forward [[Jim Pollard]] and playmaker [[Herm Schaefer]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sportsecyclopedia.com/nba/mpls/mplslakers.html |title=Minneapolis Lakers |access-date=August 15, 2008 |publisher=sportsecyclopedia |archive-date=January 19, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160119163208/http://www.sportsecyclopedia.com/nba/mpls/mplslakers.html |url-status=live }} In their first season, they led the league with a 43–17 record, later winning the NBL championship that season.Lazenby, p. 27. [[File:GeorgeMikan.jpg|left|upright|thumb|Hall of Famer [[George Mikan]] (#99) led the Lakers franchise to their first five NBA championships. He is described by the NBA's official website as the "first superstar" in league history.]] In 1948, the Lakers moved from the NBL to the [[Basketball Association of America]] (BAA), and Mikan's 28.3 point per game (ppg) scoring average set a BAA record. In the [[1949 BAA Finals]] they won the championship, beating the [[Washington Capitols]] four games to two.Lazenby, p. 31. Following the season, the BAA and the NBL merged to form the [[National Basketball Association]] (NBA).{{cite news |author1=Glenn Gaff |title=Cage peace: Form 18-team league |url=https://www.newspapers.com/article/star-tribune-cage-peace-form-18-team-le/149924180/ |access-date=23 June 2024 |work=[[Star Tribune]] |date=4 August 1949 |page=20 |via=[[Newspapers.com]]}}{{open access}} In the newly formed league, the Lakers improved to 51–17 record and won their third straight professional championship.Lazenby, pp. 40, 42. In the 1950–51 season, Mikan won his third straight scoring title at 28.4 ppg and the Lakers went 44–24 to win their second straight division title.{{cite web |url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/players/m/mikange01.html |title=George Mikan |access-date=November 10, 2010 |publisher=basketball-reference.com |archive-date=May 9, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120509043159/http://www.basketball-reference.com/players/m/mikange01.html |url-status=live }} One of those games, a 19–18 loss against the [[Fort Wayne Pistons]], became infamous as the lowest scoring game in NBA history.Sacchare (ed) (2000). p. 61 In the playoffs, they defeated the [[Indianapolis Olympians]] in three games but lost to the [[Rochester Royals]] in the next round. During the [[1951–52 NBA season|1951–52 season]], the Lakers won 40 games, finishing second in their division. They faced the [[New York Knicks]] in the [[1952 NBA Finals|NBA Finals]], which they won in seven games. In the {{nbay|1952}} season, Mikan led the NBA in rebounding, averaging 14.4 rebounds per game (rpg), and was named MVP of the [[1953 NBA All-Star Game]]. After a 48–22 regular season, the Lakers defeated the [[Fort Wayne Pistons]] in the Western playoffs to advance to [[1953 NBA Finals|the NBA Finals]].Lazenby, p. 46. They then defeated the New York Knicks to win their second straight championship. Though Lakers star George Mikan suffered from knee problems throughout the {{nbay|1953}} season, he was still able to average 18 ppg. [[Clyde Lovellette]], who was drafted in [[1952 NBA draft|1952]], helped the team win the Western Division.Lazenby, p. 49. The team won its third straight championship in the 1950s and sixth in seven seasons when it defeated the [[Syracuse Nationals]] in seven games.Lazenby, p. 50. ===1954–1958: Post-Mikan dry spell=== Following Mikan's retirement in the 1954 off-season, the Lakers struggled but still managed to win 40 games. Although they defeated the Rochester Royals in the first round of the playoffs, they were defeated by the Fort Wayne Pistons in the semifinals.{{cite web |url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/teams/MNL/1955.html |title=Minneapolis Lakers 1954–55 Roster and Statistics |access-date=August 15, 2008 |publisher=basketball-reference.com |archive-date=October 9, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211009023723/https://www.basketball-reference.com/teams/MNL/1955.html |url-status=live }} Although they had losing records the next two seasons, they made the playoffs each year. Mikan came back for the last half of the [[1955–56 NBA season|1955–56 season]], but struggled and retired for good after the season.Lazenby, p. 51. Led by Lovellette's 20.6 points and 13.5 rebounds, they advanced to the Conference Finals in 1956–57. The Lakers had one of the worst seasons in team history in 1957–58 when they won a league-low 19 games.Lazenby, p. 57. They had hired Mikan, who had been the team's general manager for the previous two seasons, as head coach to replace Kundla. Mikan was fired in January when the team was 9–30, and Kundla was rehired.{{cite news|title=Lakers Fire George Mikan|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=WPlVAAAAIBAJ&pg=4271,2121359&dq=george-mikan&hl=en|access-date=November 10, 2010|newspaper=Eugen Register-Guard|date=January 16, 1958|agency=Associated Press|archive-date=April 21, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210421134656/https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=WPlVAAAAIBAJ&pg=4271,2121359&dq=george-mikan&hl=en|url-status=live}} The Lakers earned the top pick in the [[1958 NBA draft]] and used it to select [[Elgin Baylor]]. Baylor, who was named [[NBA Rookie of the Year Award|NBA Rookie of the Year]] and co-MVP of the [[1959 NBA All-Star Game]], averaged 24.9 ppg and 15.0 rpg helping the Lakers improve to second in their division despite a 33–39 record.Sacchare (ed) (1994). p. 92–3 After upsetting the Hawks in six games in the division finals, they returned to the NBA Finals, but were swept by the Celtics, beginning their long rivalry.Lazenby, p. 91. ===1958–1968: Move to Los Angeles and Celtics rivalry=== [[File:Baylor, Chambers and West.jpeg|upright|thumb|[[Elgin Baylor]] (left) and [[Jerry West]] (right) led the team to a total of ten NBA Finals appearances in the 1960s and 1970s. Nicknamed "Mr. Clutch", West's silhouette is featured on the NBA's official logo.{{cite web|title=Jerry West|url=http://wolves.nba.com/history/players/west_bio.html|work=nba.com|access-date=November 21, 2010|archive-date=March 7, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120307174142/http://wolves.nba.com/history/players/west_bio.html|url-status=live}}{{cite news|url=https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-2010-apr-26-la-sp-crowe-20100427-story.html|title=That iconic NBA silhouette can be traced back to him|first=Jerry|last=Crowe|date=April 27, 2010|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=June 9, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110811000133/http://articles.latimes.com/2010/apr/27/sports/la-sp-crowe-20100427|archive-date=August 11, 2011|url-status=live}}]] In their [[1959–60 NBA season|last year]] in Minneapolis, the Lakers went 25–50. On January 18, 1960, the team was coming off a loss and traveling to St. Louis when their plane crash-landed.Lazenby, p. 62. Snow storms had driven the pilot 150 miles off course when he was forced to land in a cornfield. No one was hurt.Lazenby, pp. 64–5. Their record earned them the number two pick in the [[1960 NBA draft]]. The team selected [[Jerry West]] from [[West Virginia Mountaineers men's basketball|West Virginia University]].{{cite web |url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/draft/NBA_1960.html |title=1960 NBA Draft |access-date=August 18, 2008 |publisher=basketball-reference.com |archive-date=March 24, 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090324043011/http://www.basketball-reference.com/draft/NBA_1960.html |url-status=live }} During the 1960 off-season, the Lakers became the NBA's first West Coast team when owner [[Bob Short]] decided to move the team to Los Angeles.{{cite web |url=http://www.nba.com/lakers/history/lakers_history_new.html#10 |title=History of the Lakers # 10 |access-date=August 4, 2008 |publisher=Lakers.com |archive-date=February 17, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120217202906/http://www.nba.com/lakers/history/lakers_history_new.html#10 |url-status=live }} Led by Baylor's 34.8 ppg and 19.8 rpg, Los Angeles won 11 more than the year before in West's first season.{{cite web |url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/teams/LAL/1961.html |title=Los Angeles Lakers 1960–61 Roster and Statistics |access-date=November 10, 2010 |publisher=basketball-reference.com |archive-date=October 9, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211009104446/https://www.basketball-reference.com/teams/LAL/1961.html |url-status=live }} On November 15 that season, Baylor set a new NBA scoring record when he scored 71 points in a victory against the New York Knicks while grabbing 25 rebounds.{{cite web |url=http://www.nba.com/history/players/baylor_bio.html |title=Elgin Baylor |access-date=August 10, 2010 |work=nba.com |archive-date=October 30, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151030091336/http://www.nba.com/history/players/baylor_bio.html |url-status=live }} In doing so, Baylor broke his own NBA record of 64 points. Despite a losing record, the Lakers made [[1961 NBA playoffs|the playoffs]].{{cite web |url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/teams/LAL/ |title=Los Angeles Lakers Franchise Index |access-date=November 8, 2010 |publisher=basketball-reference.com |archive-date=June 12, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100612234102/http://www.basketball-reference.com/teams/LAL/ |url-status=live }} They came within two points of the [[1961 NBA Finals|NBA Finals]] when they lost in game seven of their second round series against St. Louis.{{cite web |url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/teams/LAL/1961.html |title=Los Angeles Lakers 1960–61 Roster and Statistics |access-date=November 8, 2010 |publisher=basketball-reference.com |archive-date=October 9, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211009104446/https://www.basketball-reference.com/teams/LAL/1961.html |url-status=live }} Led by Baylor and West at 38.3 and 30.8 ppg respectively,{{cite web |url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/teams/LAL/1962.html |title=Los Angeles Lakers 1961–62 Roster and Statistics |access-date=November 10, 2010 |publisher=basketball-reference.com |archive-date=November 20, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211120205802/https://www.basketball-reference.com/teams/LAL/1962.html |url-status=live }} the Lakers improved to 54–26 in [[1961–62 NBA season|1961–62]], and made the [[1962 NBA Finals|finals]]. In a game five victory, Baylor grabbed 22 rebounds and set the still-standing NBA record for points in a finals game with 61,{{cite web|title=Baylor Scores 61 for Finals Record|url=http://www.nba.com/history/baylor61_moments.html|work=nba.com|access-date=December 19, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121110005657/http://www.nba.com/history/baylor61_moments.html|archive-date=November 10, 2012|url-status=dead}} despite fouling out of the game.Lazenby, p. 87. The Lakers, however, lost to the Celtics by three points in overtime of game seven. [[Frank Selvy]], after making two jumpers in the final 40 seconds to tie the game,{{cite news|title=Celtics Win Again... But It Was Hard|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=pJAyAAAAIBAJ&pg=843,1334925&dq=los-angeles-lakers&hl=en|access-date=November 10, 2010|newspaper=The Miami News|date=April 19, 1962|agency=Associated Press}} {{Dead link|date=January 2022 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} missed a potential game-winning 18 foot [[jump shot (basketball)|jump shot]] in regulation, a miss which he said in June 2010 still haunted him more than 40 years later.{{cite news |url=http://www.stltoday.com/sports/other/article_a70ed068-9194-52bf-92a2-8a7726c025a6.html?print=1 |title=Selvy's miss in 1962 finals still stings |access-date=November 8, 2010 |work=[[St. Louis Post-Dispatch]] |date=June 20, 2010 |first=Sam |last=Farmer |archive-date=April 23, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210423221941/https://www.stltoday.com/sports/other/article_a70ed068-9194-52bf-92a2-8a7726c025a6.html?print=1 |url-status=live }} Los Angeles won 53 games in [[1962–63 NBA season|1962–63]], behind Baylor's 34.0 ppg and West's 27.1 ppg{{cite web |url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/teams/LAL/1963.html |title=Los Angeles Lakers 1962–63 Roster and Statistics |access-date=November 10, 2010 |publisher=basketball-reference.com |archive-date=October 22, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211022225832/https://www.basketball-reference.com/teams/LAL/1963.html |url-status=live }} but lost in the NBA Finals in six games to the Celtics. After falling to 42–38 and losing in the first round of the [[1964 NBA playoffs]] to the Hawks, the team won 49 games in 1964–65. The Lakers surged past the [[Baltimore Bullets (1963–73)|Baltimore Bullets]] in the division finals, behind West's record-setting 46.3 ppg in the series.Sacchare (ed) (1994). p. 402 They lost again to the Celtics in the Finals however, this time in five games.{{cite web |url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/teams/LAL/1965.html |title=Los Angeles Lakers 1964–65 Roster and Statistics |access-date=November 8, 2010 |publisher=basketball-reference.com |archive-date=October 9, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211009041321/https://www.basketball-reference.com/teams/LAL/1965.html |url-status=live }} Los Angeles lost in the finals to Boston in seven games again in 1966, this time by two points.{{cite web |url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/teams/LAL/1966.html |title=Los Angeles Lakers 1965–66 Roster and Statistics |access-date=November 8, 2010 |publisher=basketball-reference.com |archive-date=October 9, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211009041559/https://www.basketball-reference.com/teams/LAL/1966.html |url-status=live }} Down by 16 entering the fourth quarter, and 10 with a minute and a half to go, the Lakers mounted a furious rally in the closing moments, which fell just short.{{cite news|title=Celtics Claim 8th Straight Crown|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=GGtWAAAAIBAJ&pg=7006,4672069&dq=los-angeles-lakers&hl=en|access-date=November 10, 2010|newspaper=The Spokesman Review|date=April 30, 1966|agency=Associated Press|archive-date=April 21, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210421134650/https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=GGtWAAAAIBAJ&pg=7006,4672069&dq=los-angeles-lakers&hl=en|url-status=live}} After dropping to 36 wins and losing in the first round of the [[1967 NBA playoffs]], they lost in [[1968 NBA Finals|the finals]] to the Celtics again in 1968. Los Angeles moved to a brand-new arena, [[The Forum (Inglewood, California)|The Forum]], in 1967, after playing seven seasons at the [[Los Angeles Memorial Sports Arena]]. ===1968–1973: The arrival of Wilt Chamberlain=== [[File:Wilt Chamberlain 1972.jpeg|upright|thumb|[[Wilt Chamberlain]] played for Los Angeles for five seasons during the late 1960s and early 1970s. He was an integral part of their [[1971–72 Los Angeles Lakers season|1971–72 team]] that is considered one of the best in NBA history.{{cite web|title=Top 10 Teams in NBA History|url=http://wolves.nba.com/history/toptenteams_index.html|work=nba.com|access-date=November 21, 2010|archive-date=March 7, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120307174146/http://wolves.nba.com/history/toptenteams_index.html|url-status=live}}]] On July 9, 1968, the team acquired [[Wilt Chamberlain]] from the [[Philadelphia 76ers]] for Darrell Imhoff, [[Archie Clark (basketball)|Archie Clark]], and [[Jerry Chambers]].{{cite web |url=http://www.nba.com/history/players/chamberlain_bio.html |title=Wilt Chamberlain Bio |access-date=October 25, 2008 |work=NBA.com |archive-date=December 15, 2006 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061215202627/http://www.nba.com/history/players/chamberlain_bio.html |url-status=live }} In his first season as a Laker, Chamberlain set a team record by averaging a league-leading 21.1 rpg.{{cite web |url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/players/c/chambwi01.html |title=Wilt Chamberlain |access-date=November 10, 2010 |publisher=basketball-reference.com |archive-date=May 12, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130512143015/http://www.basketball-reference.com/players/c/chambwi01.html |url-status=dead }} West, Baylor, and Chamberlain each averaged over 20 points, and Los Angeles won their division.{{cite web |url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/teams/LAL/1969.html |title=Los Angeles Lakers 1968–69 Roster and Statistics |access-date=November 13, 2010 |publisher=basketball-reference.com |archive-date=October 28, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211028052245/https://www.basketball-reference.com/teams/LAL/1969.html |url-status=live }} The Lakers and Celtics again met in the [[1969 NBA Finals|finals]], and Los Angeles had home court advantage against Boston for the first time in their rivalry. They won the first game behind Jerry West's 53 points,Sacchare (ed) (1994). p. 413 and had a 3–2 lead after five.Lazenby, p. 121. Boston won the series in seven games however,Lazenby, p. 122. and earned their 11th NBA Championship in 13 seasons.Lazenby, p. 123. West was named the first-ever [[NBA Finals MVP Award|Finals MVP]]; this remains the only time that a member of the losing team has won the award.{{cite web |url=http://www.nba.com/history/finals/19681969.html |title=West's Heroics Can't Deprive Russell of 11th Title |access-date=August 19, 2008 |work=NBA.com |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101119021338/http://www.nba.com/history/finals/19681969.html |archive-date=November 19, 2010 |url-status=dead }} In [[1969–70 NBA season|1970]], West won his first scoring title at 31.2 ppg, the team returned to the [[1970 NBA Finals|finals]], and for the first time in 16 years, they did not have to face the Celtics; instead playing the New York Knicks, who defeated them 4–3.{{cite web |url=http://www.nba.com/history/finals/champions.html |title=NBA Finals: All-Time Champions |access-date=August 19, 2008 |work=NBA.com |archive-date=August 17, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170817094310/http://www.nba.com/history/finals/champions.html |url-status=live }}{{cite web |url=http://www.nba.com/history/finals/19691970.html |title=1970 NBA Finals |access-date=August 19, 2008 |work=NBA.com |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101119021337/http://www.nba.com/history/finals/19691970.html |archive-date=November 19, 2010 |url-status=dead }} The [[1970–71 NBA season|next season]] the Lakers were defeated by the [[Milwaukee Bucks]], led by future Laker Lew Alcindor (now known as [[Kareem Abdul-Jabbar]]) in the Western Conference Finals.{{cite web |url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/playoffs/NBA_1971.html |title=1971 NBA Playoff Summary |access-date=August 20, 2008 |publisher=basketball-reference.com |archive-date=October 29, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211029011401/https://www.basketball-reference.com/playoffs/NBA_1971.html |url-status=dead }} The [[1971–72 NBA season|1971–72 season]] brought several changes. Owner [[Jack Kent Cooke]] brought in [[Bill Sharman]] as head coach,{{cite web |url=http://www.nba.com/lakers/history/lakers_history_new.html#15 |title=Lakers No.15 |access-date=August 19, 2008 |publisher=Lakers.com |archive-date=February 17, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120217202906/http://www.nba.com/lakers/history/lakers_history_new.html#15 |url-status=live }} and Elgin Baylor announced his retirement early in the season after realizing that his legs were not healthy enough. Sharman increased the team's discipline.Travers. pp. 170–1 He introduced the concept of the [[shootaround]], where players would arrive at the arena early in the morning before a game to practice shots.Lazenby, p. 137. They won 14 straight games in November and all 16 games played in December. They won three straight to open the year of 1972 but on January 9, the Milwaukee Bucks ended their winning streak by defeating the Lakers, 120–104.Lazenby, p. 145. By winning 33 straight games, Los Angeles set a record for [[List of NBA longest winning streaks|longest winning streak]] of any team in major American professional team sports.{{cite web|first=Rhiannon|last=Walker|title=The day Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and the Bucks ended the longest streak in American professional sports history|date=January 10, 2018|work=Andscape|url=https://andscape.com/features/the-day-kareem-abdul-jabbar-and-the-bucks-ended-the-longest-streak-in-american-professional-sports-history/|access-date=January 8, 2023|archive-date=January 8, 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230108093640/https://andscape.com/features/the-day-kareem-abdul-jabbar-and-the-bucks-ended-the-longest-streak-in-american-professional-sports-history/|url-status=live}}{{cite web|first=Paul|last=Doyle|title=STREAKING THROUGH HISTORY|date=January 19, 2003|work=Hartford Courant|url=https://www.courant.com/news/connecticut/hc-xpm-2003-01-19-0301191181-story.html|access-date=January 8, 2023|archive-date=January 15, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210115181552/https://www.courant.com/news/connecticut/hc-xpm-2003-01-19-0301191181-story.html|url-status=live}} The Lakers won 69 games that season, which [[List of NBA teams by single season win percentage|stood as the NBA record]] for 24 years until the Chicago Bulls won 72 games in 1995–96.{{cite web |url=http://www.nba.com/features/9596bulls_bestever.html |title=The 72-Win Bulls: The Best Ever? |access-date=August 19, 2008 |work=NBA.com |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080808155000/http://www.nba.com/features/9596bulls_bestever.html |archive-date=August 8, 2008 |url-status=dead }} Chamberlain averaged a low 14.8 points but led the league in rebounding at 19.2 a game.{{cite web |url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/leagues/NBA_1972.html |title=1971–72 NBA Season Summary |access-date=August 19, 2008 |publisher=basketball-reference.com |archive-date=September 3, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110903065400/http://www.basketball-reference.com/leagues/NBA_1972.html |url-status=live }} West's 9.7 assists per game (apg) led the league, he also averaged more than 25 points, and was named MVP of the [[1972 NBA All-Star Game]]. The team failed to score 100 points just once all year,Travers. p. 173 and at the end of the season, Bill Sharman was named [[NBA Coach of the Year|Coach of the Year]].{{cite web |url=http://www.nba.com/history/awards_coachofyear.html |title=Coach of the Year |access-date=August 19, 2008 |work=NBA.com |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100808130322/http://www.nba.com/history/awards_coachofyear.html |archive-date=August 8, 2010 |url-status=dead }} The Lakers went on to reach the [[1972 NBA Finals|finals]] against the [[New York Knicks]] where they would avenge their 1970 [[1970 NBA Finals|finals]] loss by defeating them 4 games to 1. Chamberlain tallied 24 points and 29 rebounds in game five and won the [[Bill Russell NBA Finals Most Valuable Player Award|NBA Finals Most Valuable Player Award]].Lazenby, p. 149.{{cite web |url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/playoffs/NBA_1972.html |title=1972 NBA Playoff Summary |access-date=August 19, 2008 |publisher=basketball-reference.com |archive-date=October 26, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211026100702/https://www.basketball-reference.com/playoffs/NBA_1972.html |url-status=dead }} The Lakers won 60 games in the [[1972–73 NBA season|1972–73 season]], and took another Pacific Division title.{{cite web |url=http://www.nba.com/lakers/history/lakers_history_new.html#16 |title=Lakers History No.16 |access-date=August 20, 2008 |work=NBA.com |archive-date=February 17, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120217202906/http://www.nba.com/lakers/history/lakers_history_new.html#16 |url-status=live }} Wilt Chamberlain, playing in his final season, again led the league in rebounding and set the NBA record for field-goal percentage at 72.7% which stood for several decades. The team defeated the Chicago Bulls in seven games in the conference semifinals, then the [[Golden State Warriors]] in five in the Western Division Finals. They played the New York Knicks in the [[1973 NBA Finals]]. Los Angeles took the first game by three points, but New York won the series in five games.{{cite web |url=http://www.nba.com/history/finals/19721973.html |title=Knicks Win One for the 'Aged' |access-date=August 20, 2008 |work=NBA.com |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110116011529/http://www.nba.com/history/finals/19721973.html |archive-date=January 16, 2011 |url-status=dead }} ===1973–1979: Building "Showtime"=== During the [[1973–74 NBA season|1973–74 season]], the team was hampered by the loss of West, who played only 31 games before his legs gave out.{{cite web |url=http://www.nba.com/lakers/history/history.html#16 |title=Lakers No.16 |access-date=August 21, 2008 |work=NBA.com |archive-date=November 8, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121108092750/http://www.nba.com/lakers/history/history.html#16 |url-status=live }} Goodrich, averaging 25.3 points, helped the team to a late-season surge. Trailing the Golden State Warriors by three games with seven left to play, the Lakers rallied to finish 47–35 and win the Pacific Division. They made [[1974 NBA playoffs|the playoffs]] but managed just one win against Milwaukee in the conference semifinals. Following the season, West retired due to contract disagreements with Cooke, and filed a suit for unpaid back wages.Lazenby, pp. 156–8. [[File:Kareem Abdul-Jabbar 1975.jpeg|upright|thumb|left|The Lakers acquired [[Kareem Abdul-Jabbar]] in 1975.]] After missing the playoffs in the [[1974–75 NBA season|1974–75 season]], the Lakers acquired [[Kareem Abdul-Jabbar]], who had won three league MVPs by that time.Lazenby, p. 161. Abdul-Jabbar wanted out of Milwaukee, demanding a trade to either New York or Los Angeles.Lazenby, p. 158. He was traded for [[Elmore Smith]], [[Brian Winters]], [[Junior Bridgeman]], and [[David Meyers (basketball)|Dave Meyers]]. Abdul-Jabbar had his fourth MVP season in [[1975–76 NBA season|1975–76]], leading the league in rebounding, blocked shots, and minutes played.{{cite web |url=http://www.nba.com/lakers/history/history.html#17 |title=Lakers No.17 |access-date=August 21, 2008 |work=NBA.com |archive-date=November 8, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121108092750/http://www.nba.com/lakers/history/history.html#17 |url-status=live }} The Lakers struggled in January, going 3–10, and finished out of the playoffs at 40–42. West and Cooke settled their differences—and the former Laker's lawsuit—and Cooke hired him to replace Sharman as the team's coach.Lazenby, pp. 164–5. West became upset, however, when Cooke refused to spend the money necessary to acquire forward [[Julius Erving]], who the Nets were selling.Lazenby, pp. 166–7. Behind another MVP season from Abdul-Jabbar, Los Angeles won the Pacific Division, finishing the 1976–77 season a league-best 53–29.{{cite web |url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/leagues/NBA_1977.html |title=1976–77 NBA Season Summary |access-date=August 21, 2008 |publisher=basketball-reference.com |archive-date=May 1, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120501231557/http://www.basketball-reference.com/leagues/NBA_1977.html |url-status=live }} They defeated the Warriors in a seven-game series to open the postseason before being swept by Portland in the Western Conference Finals. During the off-season, Los Angeles picked up [[Jamaal Wilkes]] from Golden State and signed first-round draft pick [[Norm Nixon]]. In the first two minutes of the first game of the 1977–78 season, Abdul-Jabbar punched Bucks center [[Kent Benson]] for an overly aggressive elbow and broke his hand.Lazenby, p. 170. Two months later, a healthy Abdul-Jabbar got into an altercation with [[Houston Rockets]] center [[Kevin Kunnert]] after a rebound. The team's starting power forward, [[Kermit Washington]], who was averaging 11.5 points and 11.2 rebounds,{{cite web |url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/players/w/washike01.html |title=Kermit Washington |access-date=November 8, 2010 |publisher=basketball-reference.com |archive-date=March 21, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110321120420/http://www.basketball-reference.com/players/w/washike01.html |url-status=live }} entered the fight, and when [[Rudy Tomjanovich]] ran in from the bench to break up the action, Washington punched him in the face.Simmons. p. 90 Tomjanovich nearly died from the punch, suffering a fractured skull and other facial injuries, which prematurely ended his playing career.Lazenby, p. 173. Washington, who stated that he assumed Tomjanovich was a combatant, was suspended for two months by the NBA, and released by the Lakers.{{cite web|last=Wittmershaus|first=Eric|title=The Punch: One Night, Two Lives, and the Fight That Changed Basketball Forever|url=http://www.flakmag.com/books/punch.html|publisher=flakmag.com|access-date=November 10, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101124151121/http://flakmag.com/books/punch.html|archive-date=November 24, 2010|url-status=dead}} The team won 45 games despite being down a starter in Washington and not having Abdul-Jabbar for nearly two months, but lost in the first round of the playoffs to Seattle.{{cite web |url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/teams/LAL/1978.html |title=Los Angeles Lakers 1977–78 season |access-date=November 8, 2010 |publisher=basketball-reference.com |archive-date=October 28, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211028235046/https://www.basketball-reference.com/teams/LAL/1978.html |url-status=live }} During the 1978–79 season, the team posted a 47–35 record but lost Abdul-Jabbar led the "Showtime" Lakers to five NBA titles in the 1980s.]] In the [[1979 NBA draft]], Los Angeles selected {{nowrap|6-foot, 9-inch}} [[point guard]] [[Magic Johnson]] from [[Michigan State Spartans men's basketball|Michigan State]] with the first overall pick.{{cite web |url=http://www.nba.com/lakers/history/lakers_history_new.html#18 |title=Los Angeles Lakers History |access-date=August 4, 2008 |publisher=Lakers.com |archive-date=February 17, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120217202906/http://www.nba.com/lakers/history/lakers_history_new.html#18 |url-status=live }} It took Johnson's teammates time to acclimate themselves to his passing ability, as his "no-look" passes often caught them unaware. Once they adjusted, his passing became a key part of Los Angeles' offense.Lazenby, pp. 193, 200. The Lakers won 60 games in Johnson's rookie year, and defeated the [[1979–80 Philadelphia 76ers season|Philadelphia 76ers]] in six games in the [[1980 NBA Finals]]. Johnson won the Finals MVP award, after starting at center for the injured Abdul-Jabbar in game six, and tallying 42 points, 15 rebounds, and seven assists.{{cite web |url=http://www.nba.com/lakers/history/lakers_history_new.html#19 |title=Los Angeles Lakers History |access-date=August 4, 2008 |publisher=Lakers.com |archive-date=February 17, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120217202906/http://www.nba.com/lakers/history/lakers_history_new.html#19 |url-status=live }} The team fell off in the [[1980–81 Los Angeles Lakers season|1980–81 season]], though, as the Lakers lost Johnson for most of the season to a knee injury.{{cite web |url=http://www.nba.com/lakers/history/lakers_history_new.html#19 |title=Lakers No.19 |access-date=August 21, 2008 |publisher=Lakers.com |archive-date=February 17, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120217202906/http://www.nba.com/lakers/history/lakers_history_new.html#19 |url-status=live }} The team turned in a 54–28 record and finished second behind the [[1980–81 Phoenix Suns season|Phoenix Suns]] in the Pacific Division. The [[1980–81 Houston Rockets season|Rockets]], led by [[Moses Malone]], defeated Los Angeles in the first round of [[1981 NBA playoffs|the playoffs]]. Early in the [[1981–82 Los Angeles Lakers season|1981–82 season]], Johnson complained to the media about head coach [[Paul Westhead]] and demanded a trade.{{cite news|title=Magic Johnson says he wants a trade|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=jyodAAAAIBAJ&pg=6817,4719601&dq=magic+johnson+paul+westhead&hl=en|access-date=November 10, 2010|newspaper=The Tuscaloosa News|date=November 18, fire Westhead after Johnson outburst|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=v3JEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3478,3906214&dq=los-angeles-lakers+jerry+buss+riley+west&hl=en|access-date=November 26, p. 214. Nicknamed "[[Showtime (basketball)|Showtime]]" due to the team's new Johnson-led fast break-offense, the Lakers won the Pacific Division title and swept both the [[1981–82 Phoenix Suns season|Suns]] and [[1981–82 San Antonio Spurs season|Spurs]] in the [[1982 NBA playoffs|1982 playoffs]].Lazenby, pp. 203, 218. Los Angeles stretched its postseason winning streak to nine games by taking the first contest of the [[1982 NBA Finals|NBA Finals]] from the [[1981–82 Philadelphia 76ers season|76ers]].Lazenby, p. 218. The team won the Finals 4–2 to finish a 12–2 playoff run. On draft night in [[1982 NBA draft|1982]], the Lakers had the first overall pick (the result of a trade with Cleveland midway through the 1979–80 season, when the Lakers had sent Don Ford and a 1980 first-round pick to the Cavaliers for Butch Lee and their 1982 selection) and selected [[James Worthy]] from [[North Carolina Tar Heels men's basketball|North Carolina]].{{cite web |url=http://www.nba.com/lakers/history/lakers_history_new.html#20 |title=1982–83: A Worthy Draft Pick |access-date=August 21, 2008 |publisher=Lakers.com |archive-date=February 17, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120217202906/http://www.nba.com/lakers/history/lakers_history_new.html#20 |url-status=live }} The [[1982–83 Los Angeles Lakers season|Lakers]] won the Pacific Division at 58–24, but Worthy suffered a leg injury in the last week of the season and missed the rest of the season. Nevertheless, they advanced to play [[1982–83 Philadelphia 76ers season|Philadelphia]] in the [[1983 NBA Finals]] after defeating [[1982–83 Portland Trail Blazers season|Portland]] and [[1982–83 San Antonio Spurs season|San Antonio]].Lazenby, p. 222. The Sixers, however, won the series and the championship in four games. After the season West replaced Sharman as the team's GM.Lazenby, p. 224. In the [[1983–84 Los Angeles Lakers season|1983–84 season]], Los Angeles went 54–28, and played [[1983–84 Boston Celtics season|Boston]] in the [[1984 NBA Finals|Finals]] for the first time since [[1969 NBA Finals|1969]]. The Lakers won two of the first three games. However, [[Kevin McHale (basketball)|Kevin McHale]]'s hard [[Clothesline from hell|clothesline]] foul of Lakers forward [[Kurt Rambis]] on a fast break is credited as a turning point of the series.Lazenby, p. 235. Boston won three of the next four to win the title and send Los Angeles's record to 0–8 in Finals series against the Celtics.{{cite web|title=NBA Finals: All-Time Champions|url=http://www.nba.com/history/finals/champions.html|work=NBA.com|access-date=November 10, 2010|archive-date=August 17, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170817094310/http://www.nba.com/history/finals/champions.html|url-status=live}} Using the past year's Finals defeat as motivation, [[1984–85 Los Angeles Lakers season|the team]] won the Pacific Division for the fourth straight year and lost just two games in the [[1985 NBA playoffs|Western Conference playoffs]]. In the [[1985 NBA Finals|NBA Finals]], the [[1984–85 Boston Celtics season|Celtics]] were again the Lakers' final hurdle. Los Angeles lost game one of the NBA Finals by a score of 148–114, in what is remembered as the "Memorial Day Massacre".{{cite web |url=http://www.nba.com/history/finals/19841985.html |title=Kareem, Lakers Conquer the Celtic Mystique |access-date=August 13, 2008 |work=NBA.com |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120222182931/http://www.nba.com/history/finals/19841985.html |archive-date=February 22, 2012 |url-status=dead }} The Lakers, behind 38-year-old Finals MVP Abdul-Jabbar, recovered to defeat the Celtics in six games.Lazenby, p. 244. The team won the title in the [[Boston Garden]] and became the first visiting team to ever win an NBA championship in Boston, as the [[Golden State Warriors]] later achieved this feat in [[2021–22 Golden State Warriors season|2022]]. [[File:James Worthy at UNC Basketball game. February 10, 2007.jpg|upright|thumb|Los Angeles drafted [[James Worthy]] first overall in 1982. "Big Game James" recorded his only career [[triple-double]] in the Lakers' game seven victory over the Pistons in the 1988 NBA Finals.{{cite web|last=Hollinger|first=John|title=3. James Worthy, Lakers: 1988 Finals, Game 7|date=June 11, 2010|url=https://www.espn.com/nba/playoffs/2010/columns/story?columnist=hollinger_john&page=BestFinalsGame-Individual-3|publisher=ESPN|access-date=December 14, 2010|archive-date=January 2, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160102115115/http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/playoffs/2010/columns/story?columnist=hollinger_john&page=BestFinalsGame-Individual-3|url-status=live}}]] In the [[1985–86 Los Angeles Lakers season|1985–86 season]], the Lakers started 24–3 and went on to win 62 games and their fifth straight division title.{{cite web |url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/teams/LAL/1986.html |title=Los Angeles Lakers games in the 1985–1986 NBA season and playoffs |access-date=October 25, 2008 |publisher=basketball-reference.com |archive-date=September 15, 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080915224114/http://www.basketball-reference.com/teams/LAL/1986.html |url-status=live }} The [[1985–86 Houston Rockets season|Rockets]], however, defeated the Lakers in five games in the [[1986 NBA playoffs|Western Conference Finals]]. Houston won the series when [[Ralph Sampson]] hit a 20-foot jumper as time expired in game five at The Forum. Prior to the [[1986–87 Los Angeles Lakers season|1986–87 season]], the Lakers moved [[A.C. Green]] into the starting lineup, and acquired [[Mychal Thompson]] from the Spurs.{{cite web |url=http://www.nba.com/lakers/history/lakers_history_new.html#23 |title=Lakers History No.23 |access-date=August 17, 2008 |publisher=Lakers.com |archive-date=February 17, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120217202906/http://www.nba.com/lakers/history/lakers_history_new.html#23 |url-status=live }} Johnson won his first career MVP Award while leading the Lakers to a 65–17 record, and Michael Cooper was named NBA Defensive Player of the Year. The Lakers advanced to the [[1987 NBA Finals|NBA Finals]] by sweeping the [[1986–87 Denver Nuggets season|Nuggets]], defeating the [[1986–87 Golden State Warriors season|Warriors]] in five games, and sweeping the [[1986–87 Seattle SuperSonics season|SuperSonics]] in the [[1987 NBA playoffs|Western Conference Finals]].Lazenby, p. 250. The Lakers defeated [[1986–87 Boston Celtics season|Boston]] in the first two games of the Finals, and the teams split the next four games, giving Los Angeles their second championship in three seasons. The series was highlighted by Johnson's running "baby hook" shot to win game four at Boston Garden with two seconds remaining.{{cite web |url=http://www.nba.com/playoffs2004/challenge_lakers1987.html |title=1986–87 Los Angeles Lakers |access-date=August 14, 2008 |work=NBA.com |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080725005305/http://www.nba.com/playoffs2004/challenge_lakers1987.html |archive-date=July 25, 2008 |url-status=dead }} Johnson was named the NBA Finals MVP, in addition to regular season MVP.Lazenby, pp. 246, 253. At the Lakers' championship celebration in Los Angeles, coach Riley brashly declared that Los Angeles would repeat as NBA champions, which no team had done since the [[1968–69 Boston Celtics season|1968–69 Boston Celtics]]. Looking to make good on Riley's promise in the [[1987–88 Los Angeles Lakers season|1987–88 season]], the Lakers took their seventh consecutive Pacific Division title with a 62–20 record. They swept the [[1987–88 San Antonio Spurs season|Spurs]] in the first round of the [[1988 NBA playoffs|Western Conference Finals]] before pulling out a tough seven-game series win over the [[1987–88 Utah Jazz season|Utah Jazz]] led by youngsters [[Karl Malone]] and [[John Stockton]]. A seven-game Western Conference finals win over the [[1987–88 Dallas Mavericks season|Dallas Mavericks]] propelled the Lakers to the [[1988 NBA Finals|NBA Finals]] once again. In their seventh trip to the Finals in nine years, they met the [[1987–88 Detroit Pistons season|Detroit Pistons]]. Los Angeles would take the series in seven games, and James Worthy's game seven [[triple-double]] earned him a Finals MVP award.Lazenby, p. 264. The win marked their fifth title in nine years, but would also mark their last title until [[1999–2000 Los Angeles Lakers season|2000]]. In the [[1988–89 Los Angeles Lakers season|1988–89 season]], Los Angeles won 57 games and their eighth consecutive Pacific Division crown. They swept through the [[1989 NBA playoffs|playoffs]] defeating [[1988–89 Portland Trail Blazers season|Portland]], [[1988–89 Seattle SuperSonics season|Seattle]], and [[1988–89 Phoenix Suns season|Phoenix]]. In an eighth trip to the [[1989 NBA Finals|NBA Finals]] in 10 years, they once again faced the [[1988–89 Detroit Pistons season|Detroit Pistons]].Lazenby, p. 265. Hampered by injuries to [[Byron Scott (basketball)|Byron Scott]] and Johnson, the Lakers were swept by Detroit.{{cite web |url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/teams/LAL/1989.html |title=1988–89 Los Angeles Lakers |access-date=August 14, 2008 |publisher=basketball-reference.com |archive-date=September 13, 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080913195614/http://www.basketball-reference.com/teams/LAL/1989.html |url-status=live }} Following the 1989 Finals, on June 28, 1989, after 20 professional seasons, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar announced his retirement. [[1989–90 Los Angeles Lakers season|The Lakers]] still cruised through the Pacific Division, winning their ninth consecutive division crown with a 63–19 record. However, after beating the [[1989–90 Houston Rockets season|Rockets]] in the first round, they lost four games to one in the second round of the playoffs to the [[1989–90 Phoenix Suns season|Suns]].Lazenby, pp. 259–60. Riley announced he was stepping down after the season citing [[Occupational burnout|burnout]],Lazenby, p. 267. and was replaced by [[Mike Dunleavy Sr.|Mike Dunleavy]].Lazenby. p. 269 Riley's departure received a mixed reaction from the players. They respected his contributions, but some, such as Worthy and Scott, had grown tired of his intense practices and felt he tried to take too much credit for the team's successes.Lazenby, pp. 267–9. Following the season, 1987 [[NBA Defensive Player of the Year Award|Defensive Player of the Year]] winner [[Michael Cooper]] decided to play in Europe and was waived at his request.Lazenby. p. 269. The [[1990–91 Los Angeles Lakers season|1990–91 Lakers]] failed to win the Pacific Division for the first time in 10 years, but still finished with a 58–24 record. After cruising through the [[1991 NBA playoffs|Western Conference playoffs]], the Lakers found themselves in the [[1991 NBA Finals|NBA Finals]] once again, their ninth trip to the Finals in 12 years. The 1991 Finals represented a changing of the guard as the Lakers were defeated in five games by the [[1990–91 Chicago Bulls season|Chicago Bulls]], led by superstar [[Michael Jordan]].{{cite web |url=http://www.nba.com/history/finals/19901991.html |title=Bulls Finally Get That Championship Feeling |access-date=August 17, 2008 |work=NBA.com |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120222162648/http://www.nba.com/history/finals/19901991.html |archive-date=February 22, 2012 |url-status=dead }} ===1991–1996: Post-"Showtime" dry spell=== On November 7, 1991, Magic Johnson announced he had tested positive for [[HIV]] and would retire immediately.{{cite web |url=http://nbcsports.msnbc.com/id/15605885/site/21683474/ |title=15 years since Magic's HIV announcement |access-date=August 14, 2008 |publisher=NBC Sports |date=November 7, 2006 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120723033233/http://nbcsports.msnbc.com/id/15605885/site/21683474/ |archive-date=July 23, 2012 |url-status=dead }} In their [[1991–92 Los Angeles Lakers season|first season]] without Johnson, the team won 43 games to earn the eighth seed in the [[1992 NBA playoffs|Western Conference playoffs]]. The Lakers were defeated in the first round by [[1991–92 Portland Trail Blazers season|Portland]]. Following the season, head coach Mike Dunleavy was fired. The Lakers would lose 43 games in [[1992–93 Los Angeles Lakers season|1992–93]] under [[Randy Pfund]], their first losing season since 1976. The Lakers would still make the playoffs, and would become the first eighth seed to win the opening two games on the road against a number one seed when they took a 2–0 lead against [[1992–93 Phoenix Suns season|Phoenix]]. They lost the next two games at home however, then game five in Phoenix in overtime.Lazenby, pp. 304–5. During the [[1993–94 Los Angeles Lakers season|1993–94 season]], Pfund was fired during the season that would result in the Lakers failing to make the playoffs for the first time since 1976. Magic Johnson, would coach the final 16 games of the season with former teammate Michael Cooper as his lead assistant.Lazenby, p. 306. Johnson decided not to take the job permanently due to what he felt was a lack of commitment from certain players, and Los Angeles ended the season with a 10-game losing streak to finish 33–49.Lazenby. p. 307.Travers. p. 177 Under new coach [[Del Harris]], Los Angeles made the playoffs each of the next two seasons but was eliminated in the second and first rounds respectively.{{cite web |url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/teams/LAL/1995.html |title=Los Angeles Lakers 1994–95 Summary |access-date=August 14, 2008 |publisher=basketball-reference.com |archive-date=November 4, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211104005816/https://www.basketball-reference.com/teams/LAL/1995.html |url-status=live }}{{cite web |url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/teams/LAL/1996.html |title=Los Angeles Lakers 1995–96 Summary |access-date=August 14, 2008 |publisher=basketball-reference.com |archive-date=November 4, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211104164629/https://www.basketball-reference.com/teams/LAL/1996.html |url-status=live }} The team was led by young guards [[Nick Van Exel]] and [[Eddie Jones (basketball)|Eddie Jones]].Lazenby. p. 307 Johnson came out of retirement to return as a player in the [[1995–96 Los Angeles Lakers season|1995–96 season]] to lead the then 24–18 Lakers to a 29–11 finish.Lazenby, p. 309. After some run-ins with Van Exel, displeasure with Harris's strategies, and a first-round loss to the [[1995–96 Houston Rockets season|Rockets]], Johnson decided to retire for the final time after the season.Lazenby, pp. 309–10. ===1996–2004: O'Neal and Bryant dynasty=== [[File:Lakers banners & retired jerseys 2024.jpg|thumb|upright=1.1|Championship banners from Minneapolis and Los Angeles & retired jerseys, hanging in the rafters of Crypto.com Arena in 2024]] During the 1996 off-season, the Lakers acquired 17-year-old [[Kobe Bryant]] from the [[Charlotte Hornets]] for [[Vlade Divac]]; Bryant was drafted 13th overall out of [[Lower Merion High School]] in [[Ardmore, Pennsylvania]] in [[1996 NBA draft|that year's draft]], by Charlotte. Game four of the series would be the last game ever played at the [[The Forum (Inglewood, California)|Great Western Forum]].{{cite web |url=http://www.nba.com/lakers/history/lakers_history_new.html#34 |title=Los Angeles Lakers History |access-date=August 6, 2008 |publisher=Lakers.com |archive-date=February 17, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120217202906/http://www.nba.com/lakers/history/lakers_history_new.html#34 |url-status=live }} [[File:Shaq at the white house.jpg|thumb|left|The Lakers at the [[White House]] following their 2001 NBA championship]] Before the [[1999–2000 NBA season|1999–2000 season]], West was prepared to hire Rambis as the team's full-time coach before an outcry from fans and members of the organization caused him to seek out a bigger name.Lazenby, p. 363. Los Angeles hired former [[Chicago Bulls]] coach [[Phil Jackson]], who had coached that team to six championships, and gave him a lucrative $6 million a year contract.Lazenby, pp. 363–6. He brought along assistant [[Tex Winter]] and they installed Winter's version of the [[triangle offense]].Lazenby, p. 367. It has been called the best rivalry in the NBA.{{cite magazine |date= |title=NBA's Best Rivalries |url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/multimedia/photo_gallery/1003/nba.best.rivalries/content.1.html |url-status=dead |magazine=Sports Illustrated |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120223113032/http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/multimedia/photo_gallery/1003/nba.best.rivalries/content.1.html |archive-date=February 23, 2012 |access-date=June 3, 2011}} The two teams have met a record 12 times in the [[NBA Finals]], starting with their first Finals meeting in {{nbafy|1959}}. They would go on to dominate the league in the 1960s and the 1980s, facing each other six times in the 1960s and three times in the 1980s. The rivalry had been less intense since the retirements of [[Magic Johnson]] and [[Larry Bird]] in the early 1990s, but in 2008 it was renewed as the Celtics and Lakers met in the Finals for the first time since 1987, with the Celtics winning the series 4–2. They faced off once again in the [[2010 NBA Finals]], which the Lakers won in 7 games. The two teams were tied for the highest number of championships, with 17 titles apiece, until the Celtics surpassed this record in the [[2024 NBA Finals]]; together, the 35 championships account for almost half of the [[List of NBA champions|78 championships]] in NBA history. The all-time series record for the Lakers vs Celtics is 209–165 with the Celtics being the forerunners. After Mikan retired, attendance plummeted and the team lost money for several seasons, leading the ownership group to put the team up for sale in 1957. [[Marty Marion]], a retired baseball player and manager, and his business partner Milton Fischman attempted to purchase the team with the intention of moving the club to [[Kansas City, Missouri]].{{cite news|title=Looks like Marion will get Lakers|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=N-wcAAAAIBAJ&pg=7315,5131393&dq=lakers+ben-berger&hl=en|access-date=November 12, 2010|newspaper=Sarasota Herald Tribune|date=February 27, 1957|agency=Associated Press}}{{cite news|title=Minneapolis May Retain Laker Basketball Outfit|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=s-ZFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4696,4419766&dq=chalfen+lakers+ben-berger&hl=en|access-date=November 10, 2010|newspaper=Lawrence Journal World|date=May 12, 1957|agency=Associated Press}} Mikan offered to mortgage his home in an attempt to buy the team and keep the club in Minnesota.{{cite news|title=Mikan Offers to Buy Lakers|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=-RlUAAAAIBAJ&pg=5972,2622919&dq=chalfen+lakers+ben-berger&hl=en|access-date=November 10, 2010|newspaper=St. Joseph News Press|date=March 3, 1957|agency=United Press International}} The Lakers were sold to a group of investors led by Bob Short, however.Quirk & Fort, p. 453. Green]] and [[Vlade Divac]] in the 1980s, [[Elden Campbell]], [[Nick Van Exel]], Derek Fisher and [[Devean George]] in the 1990s, and [[Luke Walton]], [[Sasha Vujačić]], and [[Ronny Turiaf]] in the 2000s. ==Head coaches== [[File:Phil Jackson 3 cropped.jpg|right|upright|thumb|Former head coach Phil Jackson led the team to five championships.]] {{Main|List of Los Angeles Lakers head coaches}} There have been 29 head coaches for the Lakers franchise. [[John Kundla]] coached the team in Minneapolis when they won their first five [[NBA Finals|BAA/NBA championships]] from [[1949 BAA Finals|1949]] to [[1954 NBA Finals|1954]]. [[Pat Riley]] is second in franchise history in both regular season and playoff games coached and wins.{{cite web |url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/coaches/rileypa01c.html |title=Pat Riley Coaching Record |publisher=basketball-reference.com |access-date=June 21, 2008 |archive-date=March 7, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110307070039/http://www.basketball-reference.com/coaches/rileypa01c.html |url-status=dead }} Phil Jackson broke Riley's regular-season wins record in 2009, and he passed Riley's playoff wins and games coached records in 2010. Jackson, Riley, Kundla, and Bill Sharman have all been inducted into the Basketball Hall of Fame for their coaching careers. [[George Mikan]], Jim Pollard, [[Jerry West]], [[Pat Riley]], Magic Johnson, [[Kurt Rambis]], [[Byron Scott]] and [[Luke Walton]] have all played and head-coached for the Lakers. Jackson, who had two stints as head coach, was coach from 2005 to 2011. In May 2011, [[Mike Brown (basketball, born 1970)|Mike Brown]] was named his replacement for the 2011–12 season.{{cite web |url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/teams/LAL/coaches.html |title=Los Angeles Lakers Coach Register |publisher=basketball-reference.com |access-date=June 21, 2008}} Brown was fired{{cite news|last=Bresnahan |first=Mike |url=http://www.latimes.com/sports/lakersnow/la-sp-ln-lakers-coach-mike-brown-fired-replaced-20121109,0,4845829.story |title=Lakers fire Mike Brown as coach |work=Los Angeles Times |date=November 9, 2012 |access-date=January 27, 2013}} on November 9, 2012, after a 1–4 start. Assistant coach [[Bernie Bickerstaff]] served as interim head coach for five games before the Lakers selected [[Mike D'Antoni]] as their new head coach. D'Antoni resigned at the end of the 2013–14 season. In July 2014, Byron Scott was hired as head coach.{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/lakers/releases/140728byronscott_headcoach|title=Lakers Announce Hiring of Byron Scott as Head Coach|work=Los Angeles Lakers}} After the 2015–16 season ended, Scott was fired. On April 29, 2016, former Lakers player [[Luke Walton]] was named as Scott's replacement,{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/lakers/releases/160429_lukewalton|title=Lakers Announce Agreement With Luke Walton to Become New Head Coach|work=NBA.com|date=April 29, 2016|access-date=June 3, 2016}} and served as head coach until the end of the 2018–19 season.{{cite web |title=Los Angeles Lakers and Luke Walton Mutually Agree to Part Ways |url=https://www.nba.com/lakers/releases/190412-luke-walton |website=NBA.com |access-date=May 14, 2019 |date=April 12, 2019}} [[Frank Vogel]] was named his successor on a multiyear deal announced on May 13, 2019.{{cite web |title=Lakers sign Frank Vogel to multiyear head coaching contract |url=https://www.nba.com/article/2019/05/13/lakers-hire-coach-frank-vogel-release |website=NBA.com |access-date=May 27, 2019 |date=May 13, 2019}} Vogel was fired following the conclusion of the 2021–22 season.{{cite web |date=April 11, 2022 |title=Lakers fire Vogel after disappointing 33–49 year |url=https://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/33719007 |website=ESPN.com}} On June 6, 2022, [[Darvin Ham]] was named as Vogel's successor as head coach.{{cite web|url=https://www.nba.com/lakers/news/lakers-introduce-darvin-ham-6-6-22|title=Lakers Introduce Head Coach Davin Ham|last=Trudell|first=Mike|date=June 6, 2022|website=Lakers.com|access-date=December 10, 2023}} However, Ham was fired by the Lakers on May 3, 2024, after the Lakers were eliminated in Game 5 of the first round by the [[Denver Nuggets]]. He broadcast 3,338 consecutive games between November 21, 1965, and December 16, 2001.{{cite web |last=Merron |first=Jeff |title=The List: Greatest individual streaks |url=https://www.espn.com/page2/s/list/individualstreaks.html |access-date=December 6, 2023 |publisher=ESPN}} Hearn came up with West's "Mr. Clutch" nickname.Lazenby, p. 84. He was a part of the team's "inner sanctum" when Cooke was owner, and was consulted on basketball decisions.Lazenby, pp. 187–8. [[Paul Sunderland]], who had filled in for a couple of games while Hearn recuperated in the [[2001–02 NBA season|2001–02 season]], was named the permanent [[play-by-play]] announcer. [[Stu Lantz]] was retained as the [[color commentator]].{{cite web |date=September 22, 2002 |title=Paul Sunderland Joins Lakers Broadcast Team |url=http://www.nba.com/lakers/news/sunderland_broadcast_020924.html |access-date=August 4, 2008 |work=NBA.com |archive-date=January 16, 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090116034747/http://www.nba.com/lakers/news/sunderland_broadcast_020924.html |url-status=dead }} When Sunderland's contract expired in the summer of 2005, the team chose not to renew it.{{cite news |url=https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-2005-may-03-sp-sunderland3-story.html |title=Sunderland Out as Laker Announcer |access-date=August 4, 2008 |work=Los Angeles Times |date= May 3, 2005| first=Larry | last=Stewart}} Then, [[Joel Meyers]] moved in alongside Lantz as the television announcer, with [[Spero Dedes]] and former Laker player [[Mychal Thompson]] on the radio.{{cite web |url=http://www.nba.com/lakers/news/broadcast.html |title=Los Angeles Lakers Broadcast |access-date=August 8, 2008 |work=NBA.com }} For the [[2011–12 NBA season|2011–12 season]], [[Bill Macdonald]] became the new television play-by-play announcer, joining Lantz who remained as the color analyst.
